creator: dmh@dmh.org.uk
text:
Please associate the file extensions used by SVG graphics with 
the 'application/xml' MIME type:

application/xml			svg svgz

(Note: The W3C Recommendation for SVG 1.0 mentions an SVG-specific media 
type, 'image/svg+xml'.  It states it will be registered when SVG becomes a W3C 
Recommendation, i.e. September 2001.  To date, no such registration has taken 
place; however, should an SVG-specific media type become registered, it would 
make sense to use that instead of the more generic 'application/xml'.)

Many thanks.

creator: Dave@Yost.com
text:
Please go ahead and put in image/svg+xml

creator: jwoolley@apache.org
text: As a matter of policy, we will not add extensions to the mime.types file until they become recognized by IANA.  As soon as that happens, we'll be glad to add these types.  Thanks, Cliff

creator: dmh@dmh.org.uk
text:
This is why I suggested associating the de facto SVG extensions with the 
application/xml media type -- people want to use SVG graphics /now/, but we're 
stymied because SVG doesn't have it's own IANA-recognised type.  Associating it 
with a recognised XML media type strikes me as a good stop-gap, rather than 
leaving any ".svg" files to be served up as text/plain.

The only other workaround is to use the ".xml" extension for all SVG files, 
e.g. <http://www.mozilla.org.uk/svg/lion.xml>.

No wonder the kids love Flash.  ;o)

(Left bug as WONTFIX.)

Anybody who wants to use these files can easily add the mime type to their local copy of mime.types -- having it distributed by us is mostly just a convenience issue.  Unfortunately we get countless requests for types to be added, and the default mime.types file would quickly become huge if we didn't put some kind of restriction on it; namely that it has to be IANA-sanctioned.  Shrug..  Thanks for your input, though!  Let us know when IANA approves it and in it will go.  =-]
